<Rate>1<//Rate><text>If you are thinking of buying from Steven's Creek Subaru, please read this review first! MY SALES CONTRACT WAS MESSED UP TWICE AND I RECEIVED A THREATENING PHONE CALL FROM AN EMPLOYEE NAME MOHAMMED. I would hate for more customers to have the same experience I did!

While I love my Forester, I truly regret buying it from Steven's Creek Subaru. Not only did they mess up on our sales contract TWICE, but I also received an EXTREMELY HARASSING phone call from an employee named Mohammed (I am not sure of his last name. I asked, but his response, word for word, was "That's all you need to know" before he hung up on me). Here's the story behind it:

When Chase (the bank that Steven's Creek Subaru finances through) was not paying the dealership due to the errors that they made in the contract (twice...), Mohammed call me and accused me of not making my payments (of which I had already paid two). I tried to give him any information from the online payment portal to prove that I was making payments (not that I should have to do this anyway), but he did not believe me. So, Mohammed said that I needed to pay the dealership directly. Obviously, I knew that my only obligation was to make my payments to Chase, so I told him that I would absolutely not. Then, he tried to get me to call Chase to figure out the problem, which is absolutely not my responsibility, so I said no. His last resort was to threaten to cancel my contract and take my car back (both ridiculous and empty threats). At this point, I asked for his name because I felt threatened by the way he was raising his voice at me. That is when Mohammed refused to tell me his last name and hung up on me.

This conversation left me so insulted, infuriated, and shaken that I was literally in tears. I have NEVER been spoken to by anyone like that in my life. And to be treated this way for a mistake that Steven's Creek Subaru had made was absolutely ridiculous.

To be honest, I feel that Mohammed spoke down to be because I am a woman. I felt patronized by the way he spoke to me and I believe he was trying to bully me into paying them. I truly believe that he thought he could take advantage of me because I am a woman and young, but his stupid attempts failed.

After this incident, I spoke over the phone to RJ, a sales manager, who only offered what could barely pass for an apology and absolutely no explanation for why Mohammed would call me and harass me in such a way. I also called Brian Bakhtiari, the head sales manager, and left a message. He could not even be bothered to call me back.

This is the second car we have bought from Steven's Creek Subaru. I have always taken my car to get every service at their dealership as well. I was clearly a loyal customer, but if this is how they treat their "valued customers" I would hate to see how they are treating everyone else...

Since all of my other attempts to get an explanation from Steven's Creek Subaru for Mohammed's rude and unacceptable actions and some sort of remediation did not work, I am hoping that this post will at least save someone else the headache and harassment that I went through. I will never return to Steven's Creek Subaru and will make sure all my friends and family do the same.<//text>< pictures>

<Rating>2<//Rating><text>Test drives are only for people who already know they want the car.

In short: I was denied a test drive because I don't like gray cars.

I showed up at the dealership with the intention to drive a WRX and/or a WRX STI. I was greeted by a salesperson who was happy to get me the keys to fire up an STI. With the car idling, he then asked what I wanted to do and I asked if I could drive the car. He began to inform me that test drives of WRXs (and STIs) are limited to people that like the model, color, features, etc of the car and would consider buying it today. I replied honestly, saying that I was just interested in seeing how the new ('15) car differs from the old model ('14) and that I don't care for the color of the car (gray). Also, this car was used, had a floppy rear view mirror, a broken arm rest, and an unwarranted high price tag, so I definitely wouldn't be buying THIS one, but I kept that part to myself. He didn't budge on the test drive policy. I checked out a WRX, he maintained that this car too would not be available for me to test drive. It was also gray. Essentially, I've taken valuable time out of my day, stopping by this dealership on my commute how from work, only to learn about how the interiors of these cars looks and feel. I suppose I also learned that this Subaru dealership likes to pretend that even its faulty used cars are too good for test drives.

I feel the need to note that I rolled up in my '97 Camry commuter car, which I presume gave off the impression that I have no money. Well done, Stevens Creek Subaru. You saved a few miles on the car and earned some additional reputation points on the Web. Maybe if I pull up in my G35 I'll get a different treatment...

Side note: While I'm at at, I might as well warn potential buyers that there may be swirl marks on your new prospective car's paint. A while back, when looking at BRZs with my girlfriend, I noticed a new red BRZ with swirl marks shimmering in the reflection of the outside lighting at dusk.<//text><pictures>None< /pictures>< Response>

Helen Fan<//Name>
<date>1386729787144< /date>< rate>
5<//rate>
<review>I have been contemplating for a long time as to whether or not I should cash in my Honda Si for a Subaru STI and was a bit skeptical at first to make the change. When I finally bit the bullet, I was more than happy with my decision.

I conducted a lot of research prior to committing to purchasing the vehicle. I eventually ended up at the Stevens Creek Subaru dealership and was immediately assisted and approached by one of the salesman. I usually dislike going to car dealerships because I absolutely dislike how they bug you every second to try to talk you into buying a car. However, unlike most car salesmen that I have encountered who make you feel uncomfortable, are extremely pushy and make you feel like they are running some sort of shady business to rip you off, this salesman (named Cemal) who assisted me was extremely helpful, professional and courteous in helping me make a decision and evaluating my options prior to committing to buy. He seemed to be extremely educated about the vehicles and was fast and efficient during the whole process. I was pretty particular in the features I wanted on the car especially if I was going to throw down so much money on a new car so you can imagine all the questions I was inquiring about. The salesman, Cemal, was patient in wanting to help me find the car that is a good fit for my needs/wants and did not make me feel rushed. In fact, he actually shared a lot of his knowledge regarding the vehicle, that I did not know about which I found to be very helpful. I ended up sealing the deal and picked myself up a 2013 Impreza STI in black. Another one of the salesman (named Rocky) helped close the deal and also showed the same sense of professionalism and was also vey personable. This is probably the most comfortable car shopping experience I have had at a dealer lot.

Overall, I would definitely recommend this dealer lot if you are seriously considering buying a Subaru, or express an interest in getting one. Cemal even called me personally to follow-up to make sure I was satisfied with my purchase. I can't say you will get the same service with any other salesman, so make sure to request Cemal (pronounced Jamal) as your salesperson!!

BEST SUBARU SALESMAN CEMAL UNAL.<//review>< pics>
